news_summary: Recent scientific advances have uncovered new insights into viral genetics, gut health, autism subtypes, and effective exercise strategies that significantly reduce heart risks in diabetics.
news_summary_fr: Des avancées scientifiques récentes ont permis de mieux comprendre la génétique virale, la santé intestinale, les sous-types d'autisme et les stratégies d'exercice physique efficaces qui réduisent considérablement les risques cardiaques chez les diabétiques.
news_summary_es: Recientes avances científicos han descubierto nuevos conocimientos sobre genética viral, salud intestinal, subtipos de autismo y estrategias de ejercicio eficaces que reducen significativamente los riesgos cardiacos en los diabéticos.

articles.title: Scientists just resurrected the 1918 “Spanish Flu” virus—here’s what they found
articles.summary: Scientists in Switzerland have cracked open a century-old viral mystery by decoding the genome of the 1918 influenza virus from a preserved Zurich patient. This ancient RNA revealed that the virus had already adapted to humans at the very start of the pandemic, carrying mutations that made it both more infectious and more immune-resistant. By pioneering a new method to recover fragile RNA from preserved tissue, researchers gained rare insights into how flu viruses evolve. The study not only revives the history of one of humanity's deadliest outbreaks but also arms us with critical knowledge to face future pandemics with smarter, science-based strategies.
articles.content:
Researchers from the universities of Basel and Zurich have used a historical specimen from UZH's Medical Collection to decode the genome of the virus responsible for the 1918-1920 influenza pandemic in Switzerland. The genetic material of the virus reveals that it had already developed key adaptations to humans at the outset of what became the deadliest influenza pandemic in history.

New viral epidemics pose a major challenge to public health and society. Understanding how viruses evolve and learning from past pandemics are crucial for developing targeted countermeasures. The so-called Spanish flu of 1918-1920 was one of the most devastating pandemics in history, claiming some 20 to 100 million lives worldwide. And yet, until now, little has been known about how that influenza virus mutated and adapted over the course of the pandemic.

More than 100-year-old flu virus sequenced

An international research team led by Verena Schünemann, a paleogeneticist and professor of archaeological science at the University of Basel (formerly at the University of Zurich) has now reconstructed the first Swiss genome of the influenza virus responsible for the pandemic of 1918-1920. For their study, the researchers used a more than 100-year-old virus taken from a formalin-fixed wet specimen sample in the Medical Collection of the Institute of Evolutionary Medicine at UZH. The virus came from an 18-year-old patient from Zurich who had died during the first wave of the pandemic in Switzerland and underwent autopsy in July 1918.

Three key adaptations in Swiss virus genome

"This is the first time we've had access to an influenza genome from the 1918-1920 pandemic in Switzerland. It opens up new insights into the dynamics of how the virus adapted in Europe at the start of the pandemic," says last author Verena Schünemann. By comparing the Swiss genome with the few influenza virus genomes previously published from Germany and North America, the researchers were able to show that the Swiss strain already carried three key adaptations to humans that would persist in the virus population until the end of the pandemic.

Two of these mutations made the virus more resistant to an antiviral component in the human immune system - an important barrier against the transmissions of avian-like flu viruses from animals to humans. The third mutation concerned a protein in the virus's membrane that improved its ability to bind to receptors in human cells, making the virus more resilient and more infectious.

New genome-sequencing method

Unlike adenoviruses, which cause common colds and are made up of stable DNA, influenza viruses carry their genetic information in the form of RNA, which degrades much faster. "Ancient RNA is only preserved over long periods under very specific conditions. That's why we developed a new method to improve our ability to recover ancient RNA fragments from such specimens," says Christian Urban, the study's first author from UZH. This new method can now be used to reconstruct further genomes of ancient RNA viruses and enables researchers to verify the authenticity of the recovered RNA fragments.

Invaluable archives

For their study, the researchers worked hand in hand with UZH's Medical Collection and the Berlin Museum of Medical History of the Charité University Hospital. "Medical collections are an invaluable archive for reconstructing ancient RNA virus genomes. However, the potential of these specimens remains underused," says Frank Rühli, co-author of the study and head of the Institute of Evolutionary Medicine at UZH.

The researchers believe the results of their study will prove particularly important when it comes to tackling future pandemics. "A better understanding of the dynamics of how viruses adapt to humans during a pandemic over a long period of time enables us to develop models for future pandemics," Verena Schünemann says. "Thanks to our interdisciplinary approach that combines historico-epidemiological and genetic transmission patterns, we can establish an evidence-based foundation for calculations," adds Kaspar Staub, co-author from UZH. This will require further reconstructions of virus genomes as well as in-depth analyses that include longer intervals.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding the 1918 influenza virus, which provides critical knowledge to better prepare for future pandemics. This advancement in medical science is likely to inspire hope and confidence in disease prevention and control.
articles.personality_title: Scientists unlock century-old flu virus secrets to help fight future pandemics
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long been puzzled by the deadly 1918 influenza pandemic, which caused millions of deaths worldwide. Understanding how that virus worked could help us better prepare for new viral outbreaks.

**What happened**
Researchers in Switzerland successfully decoded the genetic code of the 1918 flu virus from a preserved patient sample. They used a new technique to carefully recover fragile RNA, the virus’s genetic material, from old tissue. This revealed the virus had already adapted to humans at the very start of the pandemic, with changes that made it more infectious and better at dodging our immune system.

**Impact**
This breakthrough gives scientists valuable insight into how dangerous viruses evolve. Knowing which mutations made the 1918 flu so deadly helps us understand what to watch for in new viruses. This knowledge strengthens our ability to develop smarter vaccines and treatments to protect people in future outbreaks.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to use these findings to study other viruses and improve pandemic preparedness worldwide. They hope this method of recovering ancient viral RNA can unlock more secrets from past outbreaks.

**One-sentence takeaway**
By revealing how the 1918 flu virus adapted to humans, scientists are better equipped to fight future pandemics with smarter strategies.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques dévoilent les secrets du virus de la grippe de 1918 pour mieux lutter contre les pandémies futures
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques se sont longtemps interrogés sur la pandémie de grippe de 1918, qui a causé des millions de morts dans le monde. Comprendre ce virus pourrait nous aider à mieux nous préparer aux nouvelles épidémies virales.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des chercheurs en Suisse ont réussi à décoder le code génétique du virus de la grippe de 1918 à partir d'un échantillon de patient conservé. Ils ont utilisé une nouvelle technique pour récupérer délicatement l'ARN fragile, le matériel génétique du virus, dans un tissu ancien. Cela a révélé que le virus s'était déjà adapté aux humains au tout début de la pandémie, avec des changements le rendant plus contagieux et plus résistant au système immunitaire.

**Impact**
Cette avancée offre aux scientifiques des informations précieuses sur l'évolution des virus dangereux. Connaître les mutations qui ont rendu la grippe de 1918 si mortelle aide à identifier ce qu'il faut surveiller chez les nouveaux virus. Cette connaissance renforce notre capacité à développer des vaccins et traitements plus efficaces.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient d'utiliser ces découvertes pour étudier d'autres virus et améliorer la préparation aux pandémies dans le monde. Ils espèrent que cette méthode de récupération de l'ARN viral ancien permettra de révéler plus de secrets des épidémies passées.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
En révélant comment le virus de la grippe de 1918 s'est adapté aux humains, les scientifiques sont mieux armés pour lutter contre les futures pandémies avec des stratégies plus intelligentes.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos revelan secretos del virus de la gripe de 1918 para enfrentar mejor futuras pandemias
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Durante mucho tiempo, los científicos se han preguntado sobre la pandemia de gripe de 1918, que causó millones de muertes en todo el mundo. Entender ese virus podría ayudarnos a prepararnos mejor para nuevos brotes virales.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores en Suiza lograron descifrar el código genético del virus de la gripe de 1918 a partir de una muestra de un paciente conservado. Usaron una nueva técnica para recuperar cuidadosamente el frágil ARN, el material genético del virus, de un tejido antiguo. Esto reveló que el virus ya se había adaptado a los humanos al inicio de la pandemia, con cambios que lo hacían más contagioso y mejor para evadir el sistema inmunológico.

**Impacto**
Este avance brinda a los científicos información valiosa sobre cómo evolucionan los virus peligrosos. Saber qué mutaciones hicieron que la gripe de 1918 fuera tan mortal ayuda a entender qué debemos vigilar en nuevos virus. Este conocimiento fortalece nuestra capacidad para desarrollar vacunas y tratamientos más inteligentes para proteger a las personas en futuros brotes.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean usar estos hallazgos para estudiar otros virus y mejorar la preparación ante pandemias en todo el mundo. Esperan que este método para recuperar ARN viral antiguo pueda revelar más secretos de brotes pasados.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Al mostrar cómo el virus de la gripe de 1918 se adaptó a los humanos, los científicos están mejor preparados para enfrentar futuras pandemias con estrategias más inteligentes.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, softly colored painting of an antique glass medical specimen jar containing a delicate, glowing double-helix strand of RNA floating above a vintage autopsy table, surrounded by gentle rays of light that symbolize discovery and progress, set against a calm, neutral background that evokes a historical medical research setting.

articles.title: This bedtime snack swap could rewire your gut and help prevent diabetes
articles.summary: A new study reveals that swapping a typical nighttime carbohydrate snack for pistachios may beneficially alter gut bacteria in people with prediabetes. Conducted by Penn State researchers, the 12-week clinical trial found that pistachio consumption increased beneficial gut microbes like Roseburia and reduced harmful ones such as Blautia hydrogenotrophica. These microbiome changes could potentially support metabolic health and slow the progression to Type 2 diabetes. While more research is needed to confirm health outcomes, this study positions pistachios as a promising late-night snack with microbiome-boosting potential.
articles.content:
Prediabetes affects a third of people in the United States and most of them will develop Type 2 diabetes, yet effective dietary intervention strategies remain limited. Pistachios have shown promise in improving markers of diet quality, yet little is known about how they influence the gut microbiome -- a key player in glucose regulation and inflammation.

A new study led by Kristina Petersen, associate professor of nutritional sciences at Penn State, determined that nighttime pistachio consumption affects gut bacteria in adults with prediabetes. Though the potential therapeutic implications of the findings remain unclear, according to Petersen, they may prove significant for people who are working to improve their metabolic health.

The findings, published in the journal Current Developments in Nutrition, suggested that replacing a traditional carbohydrate-based bedtime snack with pistachios may reshape the gut microbiome. A previous study by these researchers demonstrated that pistachios have a similar effect on blood glucose as 15 to 30 grams of carbohydrates.

"A common dietary recommendation for individuals with prediabetes is to consume a nighttime snack consisting of 15 to 30 grams of carbohydrates to help regulate overnight and morning blood glucose levels," said Terrence Riley, lead author of this research who earned his doctorate in nutritional sciences at Penn State and currently works as a postdoctoral research fellow at Louisiana State University. "As an example, you could eat one or two slices of whole grain bread."

Researchers observed that consuming about two ounces of pistachios each night for 12 weeks resulted in significantly different stool microbial community profiles compared to those who consumed the recommended 15 to 30 grams of a carbohydrate snack. Specific bacterial groups, including Roseburia and members of the Lachnospiraceae family -- known as "good" bacteria that produces beneficial short-chain fatty acids like butyrate -- were more abundant following the pistachio condition.

According to Petersen, butyrate serves as a primary energy source for colon cells, helps maintain the gut barrier and supports anti-inflammatory processes.

"Pistachios seem to be able to meaningfully shift the gut microbial landscape in adults with prediabetes especially when consumed as a nighttime snack," Petersen said. "These microbiome changes may offer other long-term health benefits -- potentially helping to slow the development of Type 2 diabetes or to reduce systemic inflammation -- which we hope to explore in future research."

The study involved 51 adults with prediabetes and was conducted over two 12-week periods separated by a break, so the effects of the first part of the trial would not affect the second part. By the end of the study, all participants received both treatments. Stool samples were collected and analyzed using 16S rRNA gene sequencing, a technique that can help classify bacteria based on their genetic makeup.

Petersen noted that participants who ate pistachios also experienced reductions in several bacterial groups that have been linked to less favorable metabolic outcomes.

"Levels of Blautia hydrogenotrophica -- a bacterium that helps produce compounds that can build up in the blood and harm kidney and heart health -- were lower after pistachio consumption," Petersen said. "Levels of Eubacterium flavonifractor, which breaks down beneficial antioxidant compounds from foods like pistachios, also decreased."

Petersen added that the strength of this study is the design used -- a randomized crossover clinical trial, in which all participants receive both treatments in a randomized order. By including all participants in the pistachio group and the standard care group, the study helped the researchers better understand how specific foods like pistachios can influence the gut microbiome.

While the study demonstrated shifts in gut bacteria, it remains unclear whether these changes directly translate to improvements in health -- a question that requires further research, Petersen said.

Jordan Bisanz, assistant professor of biochemistry and molecular biology at Penn State; Penny Kris-Etherton, retired professor of nutritional sciences at Penn State; Justin Wright of Wright Labs, LLC; and Regina Lamendella, Jeremy Chen See and Khushi Kanani of Juniata College all contributed to this research.

The study was funded by the American Pistachio Growers, Penn State's Clinical and Translational Science Institute through the National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences of the National Institutes of Health, and additional support from Juniata College and the U.S. National Science Foundation. It is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT04056208).

At Penn State, researchers are solving real problems that impact the health, safety and quality of life of people across the commonwealth, the nation and around the world.

For decades, federal support for research has fueled innovation that makes our country safer, our industries more competitive and our economy stronger. Recent federal funding cuts threaten this progress.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a promising medical advance where a simple dietary change could beneficially alter gut bacteria and potentially prevent the progression of prediabetes to Type 2 diabetes, offering hope for improved metabolic health.
articles.personality_title: Swapping your bedtime snack for pistachios could boost gut health and help prevent diabetes
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Prediabetes affects about one in three people in the U.S., and many go on to develop Type 2 diabetes. While changing diet is known to help, finding specific foods that improve gut health—a key factor in blood sugar control—has been a challenge.

**What happened**
A 12-week study by Penn State researchers tested swapping a typical nighttime carb snack for pistachios in people with prediabetes. They found that eating pistachios at night increased good gut bacteria like Roseburia and decreased harmful ones such as Blautia hydrogenotrophica. These changes in gut microbes are important because they can influence how the body handles sugar and inflammation.

**Impact**
By improving the balance of gut bacteria, pistachios may help keep blood sugar levels healthier and slow the progression toward Type 2 diabetes. This simple snack swap offers a hopeful, tasty way to support metabolic health.

**What's next step**
More research is needed to confirm how these gut changes affect long-term health. But the study opens the door for pistachios to be recommended as a beneficial late-night snack for people at risk of diabetes.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Switching to pistachios as a bedtime snack could positively reshape your gut bacteria and help prevent diabetes progression.
articles.personality_title_fr: Changer votre collation du soir pour des pistaches pourrait améliorer votre digestion et prévenir le diabète
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le prédiabète touche environ un tiers des Américains, et beaucoup développent ensuite un diabète de type 2. Bien que changer son alimentation soit utile, il est difficile de trouver des aliments spécifiques qui améliorent la santé intestinale, un facteur clé dans la régulation du sucre sanguin.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une étude de 12 semaines menée par des chercheurs de Penn State a testé le remplacement d’une collation nocturne riche en glucides par des pistaches chez des personnes prédiabétiques. Ils ont découvert que manger des pistaches le soir augmentait les bonnes bactéries intestinales comme Roseburia et diminuait les mauvaises, telles que Blautia hydrogenotrophica. Ces changements sont importants car ils influencent la gestion du sucre et l’inflammation dans le corps.

**Impact**
En améliorant l’équilibre des bactéries intestinales, les pistaches pourraient aider à mieux contrôler la glycémie et à ralentir l’évolution vers le diabète de type 2. Ce simple changement de collation offre une solution savoureuse et pleine d’espoir pour la santé métabolique.

**Prochaine étape**
D’autres recherches sont nécessaires pour confirmer l’effet de ces changements sur la santé à long terme. Mais cette étude ouvre la voie à la recommandation des pistaches comme collation nocturne bénéfique pour les personnes à risque.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Changer votre collation du soir pour des pistaches pourrait transformer votre flore intestinale et aider à prévenir le diabète.
articles.personality_title_es: Cambiar tu snack nocturno por pistachos podría mejorar tu salud intestinal y ayudar a prevenir la diabetes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La prediabetes afecta a cerca de un tercio de las personas en Estados Unidos, y muchas desarrollan diabetes tipo 2. Aunque cambiar la dieta ayuda, es difícil encontrar alimentos específicos que mejoren la salud intestinal, un factor clave en el control del azúcar en sangre.

**Qué pasó**
Un estudio de 12 semanas realizado por investigadores de Penn State probó cambiar un snack nocturno típico de carbohidratos por pistachos en personas con prediabetes. Descubrieron que comer pistachos por la noche aumentó bacterias buenas del intestino como Roseburia y redujo bacterias dañinas como Blautia hydrogenotrophica. Estos cambios son importantes porque influyen en cómo el cuerpo maneja el azúcar y la inflamación.

**Impacto**
Al mejorar el equilibrio de bacterias intestinales, los pistachos podrían ayudar a mantener niveles de azúcar más saludables y retrasar el desarrollo de la diabetes tipo 2. Este cambio simple de snack ofrece una forma sabrosa y esperanzadora de apoyar la salud metabólica.

**Próximo paso**
Se necesita más investigación para confirmar cómo estos cambios en el intestino afectan la salud a largo plazo. Pero el estudio abre la posibilidad de recomendar pistachos como un snack nocturno beneficioso para quienes están en riesgo de diabetes.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Cambiar a pistachos como snack antes de dormir podría modificar positivamente tus bacterias intestinales y ayudar a prevenir la progresión de la diabetes.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a cozy nighttime kitchen scene featuring a small bowl of pistachios glowing gently on a wooden table beside a simple plate with a few whole grain bread slices, with swirling abstract representations of friendly, smiling gut bacteria in vibrant but soft colors floating around them, symbolizing a healthy, balanced gut microbiome and metabolic well-being.

articles.title: Four hidden types of autism revealed — and each tells a different genetic story
articles.summary: Scientists at Princeton and the Simons Foundation have identified four biologically distinct subtypes of autism, using data from over 5,000 children and a powerful new computational method. These subtypes—each with unique traits, developmental paths, and genetic signatures—promise to revolutionize how we understand, diagnose, and treat autism.
articles.content:
Researchers at Princeton University and the Simons Foundation have identified four clinically and biologically distinct subtypes of autism, marking a transformative step in understanding the condition's genetic underpinnings and potential for personalized care.

Analyzing data from over 5,000 children in SPARK, an autism cohort study funded by the Simons Foundation, the researchers used a computational model to group individuals based on their combinations of traits. The team used a "person-centered" approach that considered a broad range of over 230 traits in each individual, from social interactions to repetitive behaviors to developmental milestones, rather than searching for genetic links to single traits.

This approach enabled the discovery of clinically relevant autism subtypes, which the researchers linked to distinct genetic profiles and developmental trajectories, offering new insights into the biology underlying autism. Their results were published July 9 in Nature Genetics.

"Understanding the genetics of autism is essential for revealing the biological mechanisms that contribute to the condition, enabling earlier and more accurate diagnosis, and guiding personalized care," said senior study author Olga Troyanskaya, director of Princeton Precision Health, the Maduraperuma/Khot Professor of Computer Science and the Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics at Princeton, and deputy director for genomics at the Center for Computational Biology of the Simons Foundation's Flatiron Institute.

The study defines four subtypes of autism -- Social and Behavioral Challenges, Mixed ASD with Developmental Delay, Moderate Challenges, and Broadly Affected. Each subtype exhibits distinct developmental, medical, behavioral and psychiatric traits, and importantly, different patterns of genetic variation.

Individuals in the Social and Behavioral Challenges group show core autism traits, including social challenges and repetitive behaviors, but generally reach developmental milestones at a pace similar to children without autism. They also often experience co-occurring conditions like ADHD, anxiety, depression or obsessive-compulsive disorder alongside autism. One of the larger groups, this constitutes around 37% of the participants in the study.

group show core autism traits, including social challenges and repetitive behaviors, but generally reach developmental milestones at a pace similar to children without autism. They also often experience co-occurring conditions like ADHD, anxiety, depression or obsessive-compulsive disorder alongside autism. One of the larger groups, this constitutes around 37% of the participants in the study. The Mixed ASD with Developmental Delay group tends to reach developmental milestones, such as walking and talking, later than children without autism, but usually does not show signs of anxiety, depression or disruptive behaviors. "Mixed" refers to differences within this group with respect to repetitive behaviors and social challenges. This group represents approximately 19% of the participants.

group tends to reach developmental milestones, such as walking and talking, later than children without autism, but usually does not show signs of anxiety, depression or disruptive behaviors. "Mixed" refers to differences within this group with respect to repetitive behaviors and social challenges. This group represents approximately 19% of the participants. Individuals with Moderate Challenges show core autism-related behaviors, but less strongly than those in the other groups, and usually reach developmental milestones on a similar track to those without autism. They generally do not experience co-occurring psychiatric conditions. Roughly 34% of participants fall into this category.

show core autism-related behaviors, but less strongly than those in the other groups, and usually reach developmental milestones on a similar track to those without autism. They generally do not experience co-occurring psychiatric conditions. Roughly 34% of participants fall into this category. The Broadly Affected group faces more extreme and wide-ranging challenges, including developmental delays, social and communication difficulties, repetitive behaviors and co-occurring psychiatric conditions like anxiety, depression and mood dysregulation. This is the smallest group, accounting for around 10% of the participants.

"These findings are powerful because the classes represent different clinical presentations and outcomes, and critically we were able to connect them to distinct underlying biology," said Aviya Litman, a Ph.D. student at Princeton and co-lead author.

Distinct genetics behind the subtypes

For decades, autism researchers and clinicians have been seeking robust definitions of autism subtypes to aid in diagnosis and care. Autism is known to be highly heritable, with many implicated genes.

"While genetic testing is already part of the standard of care for people diagnosed with autism, thus far, this testing reveals variants that explain the autism of only about 20% of patients," said study co-author Jennifer Foss-Feig, a clinical psychologist at the Seaver Autism Center for Research and Treatment at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and vice president and senior scientific officer at the Simons Foundation Autism Research Initiative (SFARI). This study takes an approach that differs from classic gene discovery efforts by identifying robust autism subtypes that are linked to distinct types of genetic mutations and affected biological pathways.

For example, children in the Broadly Affected group showed the highest proportion of damaging de novo mutations -- those not inherited from either parent -- while only the Mixed ASD with Developmental Delay group was more likely to carry rare inherited genetic variants. While children in both of these subtypes share some important traits like developmental delays and intellectual disability, these genetic differences suggest distinct mechanisms behind superficially similar clinical presentations.

"These findings point to specific hypotheses linking various pathways to different presentations of autism," said Litman, referring to differences in biology between children with different autism subtypes.

Moreover, the researchers identified divergent biological processes affected in each subtype. "What we're seeing is not just one biological story of autism, but multiple distinct narratives," said Natalie Sauerwald, associate research scientist at the Flatiron Institute and co-lead author. "This helps explain why past genetic studies often fell short -- it was like trying to solve a jigsaw puzzle without realizing we were actually looking at multiple different puzzles mixed together. We couldn't see the full picture, the genetic patterns, until we first separated individuals into subtypes."

Autism biology unfolds on different timelines

The team also found that autism subtypes differ in the timing of genetic disruptions' effects on brain development. Genes switch on and off at specific times, guiding different stages of development. While much of the genetic impact of autism was thought to occur before birth, in the Social and Behavioral Challenges subtype -- which typically has substantial social and psychiatric challenges, no developmental delays, and a later diagnosis -- mutations were found in genes that become active later in childhood. This suggests that, for these children, the biological mechanisms of autism may emerge after birth, aligning with their later clinical presentation.

"By integrating genetic and clinical data at scale, we can now begin to map the trajectory of autism from biological mechanisms to clinical presentation," said co-author Chandra Theesfeld, senior academic research manager at the Lewis-Sigler Institute and Princeton Precision Health.

A paradigm shift for autism research

This study builds on more than a decade of autism genomics research led by Troyanskaya and collaborators, supported by the Simons Foundation and the U.S. National Institutes of Health, and most recently by Princeton Precision Health, an interdisciplinary initiative launched in 2022. It is enabled by the close integration of interdisciplinary expertise in genomics, clinical psychology, molecular biology, computer science and modeling, and computational biology -- with experts from Princeton Precision Health, the Flatiron Institute and SFARI.

"It's a whole new paradigm, to provide these groups as a starting point for investigating the genetics of autism," said Theesfeld. Instead of searching for a biological explanation that encompasses all individuals with autism, researchers can now investigate the distinct genetic and biological processes driving each subtype.

This shift could reshape both autism research and clinical care -- helping clinicians anticipate different trajectories in diagnosis, development and treatment. "The ability to define biologically meaningful autism subtypes is foundational to realizing the vision of precision medicine for neurodevelopmental conditions," said Sauerwald.

While the current work defines four subtypes, "this doesn't mean there are only four classes," said Litman. "It means we now have a data-driven framework that shows there are at least four -- and that they are meaningful in both the clinic and the genome."

Looking ahead

For families navigating autism, knowing which subtype of autism their child has can offer new clarity, tailored care, support and community. "Understanding genetic causes for more individuals with autism could lead to more targeted developmental monitoring, precision treatment, and tailored support and accommodations at school or work," said Foss-Feig. "It could tell families, when their children with autism are still young, something more about what symptoms they might -- or might not -- experience, what to look out for over the course of a lifespan, which treatments to pursue, and how to plan for their future."

Beyond its contributions to understanding autism subtypes and their underlying biology, the study offers a powerful framework for characterizing other complex, heterogeneous conditions and finding clinically relevant disease subtypes. As Theesfeld put it: "This opens the door to countless new scientific and clinical discoveries."

The paper, "Decomposition of phenotypic heterogeneity in autism reveals underlying genetic programs," was published July 9 in Nature Genetics. In addition to Litman, Sauerwald, Foss-Feig, Theesfeld and Troyanskaya, co-authors include LeeAnne Green Snyder of the Simons Foundation, Christopher Y. Park and Yun Hao of the Flatiron Institute, and Ilan Dinstein of Ben Gurion University of the Negev, who contributed to the study during a sabbatical at the Simons Foundation. The research was supported in part by the U.S. National Institutes of Health and the Simons Foundation.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of four biologically distinct subtypes of autism represents a significant scientific breakthrough that can improve understanding, diagnosis, and treatment of autism, offering hope to many affected individuals and their families.
articles.personality_title: Four hidden types of autism uncovered, each with a unique genetic story
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long known autism is a complex condition, but understanding its many forms has been a challenge. Autism varies widely among individuals, making diagnosis and treatment difficult.

**What happened**
Researchers from Princeton University and the Simons Foundation analyzed data from over 5,000 children using a new computer method that looks closely at each person’s traits. They discovered four distinct types of autism, each with its own genetic fingerprint and developmental path. This method grouped children by shared features, revealing hidden patterns.

**Impact**
This discovery is a big step forward. Knowing the specific subtype of autism a person has can help doctors tailor treatments and support more effectively. It also opens doors for new research focused on the unique biology behind each subtype.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to study these four autism types further to develop personalized therapies. The hope is to create tests that quickly identify which subtype a child has, leading to earlier and better-targeted care.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Identifying four unique autism subtypes offers new hope for personalized diagnosis and treatment, improving lives for many families.
articles.personality_title_fr: Quatre types cachés d'autisme révélés, chacun avec une histoire génétique unique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques savent depuis longtemps que l'autisme est une condition complexe, mais en comprendre les nombreuses formes restait un défi. L'autisme varie beaucoup d'une personne à l'autre, ce qui complique le diagnostic et le traitement.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des chercheurs de l'Université de Princeton et de la Fondation Simons ont analysé les données de plus de 5 000 enfants avec une nouvelle méthode informatique qui examine de près les traits de chaque personne. Ils ont découvert quatre types distincts d'autisme, chacun ayant son propre profil génétique et un parcours de développement différent. Cette méthode a regroupé les enfants selon leurs caractéristiques communes, révélant des schémas cachés.

**Impact**
Cette découverte est une avancée majeure. Connaître le type précis d'autisme d'une personne aide les médecins à adapter les traitements et le soutien de manière plus efficace. Cela ouvre aussi la voie à de nouvelles recherches sur la biologie propre à chaque type.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques prévoient d’étudier davantage ces quatre types d'autisme pour créer des thérapies personnalisées. L’espoir est de développer des tests permettant d’identifier rapidement le type d'autisme chez un enfant, pour un soin plus précoce et mieux ciblé.

**En une phrase**
Identifier quatre sous-types uniques d'autisme offre un nouvel espoir pour un diagnostic et un traitement personnalisés, améliorant la vie de nombreuses familles.
articles.personality_title_es: Cuatro tipos ocultos de autismo revelados, cada uno con una historia genética única
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos han sabido durante mucho tiempo que el autismo es una condición compleja, pero entender sus muchas formas ha sido un desafío. El autismo varía mucho entre individuos, lo que dificulta el diagnóstico y el tratamiento.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores de la Universidad de Princeton y la Fundación Simons analizaron datos de más de 5,000 niños usando un nuevo método computacional que examina de cerca los rasgos de cada persona. Descubrieron cuatro tipos distintos de autismo, cada uno con su propia huella genética y camino de desarrollo. Este método agrupó a los niños según características compartidas, revelando patrones ocultos.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento es un gran avance. Saber el subtipo específico de autismo que tiene una persona ayuda a los médicos a adaptar los tratamientos y apoyos de forma más efectiva. También abre la puerta a nuevas investigaciones enfocadas en la biología única de cada subtipo.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean estudiar más a fondo estos cuatro tipos de autismo para desarrollar terapias personalizadas. La esperanza es crear pruebas que identifiquen rápidamente qué subtipo tiene un niño, para un cuidado más temprano y mejor dirigido.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Identificar cuatro subtipos únicos de autismo ofrece nueva esperanza para un diagnóstico y tratamiento personalizado, mejorando la vida de muchas familias.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of four distinct, colorful puzzle pieces gently fitting together over a softly glowing DNA double helix, each piece uniquely patterned to symbolize different genetic codes and developmental pathways, set against a calm background of interconnected neural-like branches in natural, muted tones.

articles.title: Just two workouts a week could cut heart death risk by 33% in diabetics
articles.summary: Even if you're cramming your workouts into the weekend, you might be doing your heart a big favor—especially if you have diabetes. A large study of over 50,000 adults with diabetes found that both “weekend warriors” and those who spread out their exercise during the week saw significant reductions in all-cause and cardiovascular mortality risks. Surprisingly, the pattern of exercise didn’t matter as long as the total time met current health guidelines. That means squeezing in your 150 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity over one or two days can be just as beneficial as spreading it out over several sessions.
articles.content:
The researchers found that insufficiently active, weekend warrior, and regularly active participants had lower risks for all-cause and cardiovascular mortality compared to inactive participants. Weekend warriors and regularly active participants had a 21% and 17% lower all-cause mortality risk and 33% and 19% lower risks of cardiovascular mortality, respectively, compared with inactive participants. There were fewer differences by cancer mortality compared with physical inactivity.

Researchers from Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Boston University School of Public Health, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Capital Medical University, and colleagues studied data from 51,650 adults with self-reported diabetes who participated in the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) between 1997 and 2018. Current guidelines recommend at least 150 minutes per week of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) distributed across a minimum of three days. Participants were categorized into four activity patterns: inactive (no reported MVPA); insufficiently active (MVPA less than 150 minutes per week); weekend warrior (MVPA 150 or more minutes per week across one to two sessions); and regularly active (MVPA 150 or more minutes per week across at least three sessions).

A prospective cohort study examined the associations of different physical activity patterns with all-cause, cardiovascular (CV) and cancer mortality among adults with diabetes. The study found that weekend warrior and regular activity patterns meeting current physical activity recommendations were associated with similarly reduced risks for all-cause and cardiovascular mortality compared to physical inactivity, demonstrating the importance of any physical activity for people with diabetes. The results are published in Annals of Internal Medicine.

Materials provided by American College of Physicians . Note: Content may be edited for style and length.

articles.reasoning: The article presents a positive medical finding that even limited exercise can significantly reduce heart-related death risk in diabetics, offering hope and practical guidance for improving health outcomes.
articles.personality_title: Just two workouts a week can cut heart death risk by a third for diabetics
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Many people with diabetes worry about their heart health since they are at higher risk of heart-related problems. Exercise is known to help, but busy schedules often make it hard to fit regular workouts into the week.

**What happened**
A large study of more than 50,000 adults with diabetes showed that even those who do all their exercise during the weekend — called "weekend warriors" — have a much lower risk of dying from heart disease. In fact, doing 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous exercise spread over one or two days was just as good as breaking it into several sessions during the week.

**Impact**
The study found weekend warriors had a 33% lower risk of dying from heart problems compared to inactive people. They also had a 21% lower risk of dying from any cause. This means squeezing in exercise whenever possible can make a big difference for heart health, especially for those managing diabetes.

**What's next step**
Doctors and health experts can encourage people with diabetes to aim for at least 150 minutes a week of activity, even if it’s all done on weekends. Making exercise flexible and realistic helps people stick with it and protect their heart health more effectively.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Just two workouts a week can dramatically cut the risk of heart death for people with diabetes, proving that every bit of exercise counts no matter the schedule.
articles.personality_title_fr: Deux séances d'exercice par semaine réduisent d'un tiers le risque de décès cardiaque chez les diabétiques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Beaucoup de personnes diabétiques s'inquiètent pour leur santé cardiaque, car elles sont plus exposées aux problèmes du cœur. L'exercice aide, mais il est souvent difficile de trouver du temps pour faire du sport régulièrement pendant la semaine.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Une grande étude portant sur plus de 50 000 adultes diabétiques a montré que même ceux qui font tout leur exercice pendant le week-end — appelés "weekend warriors" — ont un risque beaucoup plus faible de mourir de maladies cardiaques. En fait, faire 150 minutes d'activité modérée à intense sur un ou deux jours est aussi efficace que de répartir les séances tout au long de la semaine.

**Impact**
L'étude a révélé que les "weekend warriors" ont un risque réduit de 33 % de mourir de maladies cardiaques par rapport aux personnes inactives. Leur risque de décès toutes causes confondues est également réduit de 21 %. Cela montre que faire de l'exercice quand on le peut peut vraiment améliorer la santé du cœur, surtout pour les diabétiques.

**Prochaine étape**
Les médecins et experts en santé peuvent encourager les diabétiques à viser au moins 150 minutes d'activité par semaine, même si cela se fait uniquement le week-end. Rendre l'exercice flexible et accessible aide les gens à persévérer et à mieux protéger leur cœur.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Deux séances d'exercice par semaine peuvent réduire considérablement le risque de décès cardiaque chez les diabétiques, prouvant que chaque moment d'exercice compte, quel que soit le planning.
articles.personality_title_es: Solo dos entrenamientos a la semana pueden reducir en un tercio el riesgo de muerte cardíaca en diabéticos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Muchas personas con diabetes se preocupan por su salud cardíaca, ya que tienen mayor riesgo de problemas del corazón. Se sabe que el ejercicio ayuda, pero a menudo es difícil encontrar tiempo para hacer ejercicio regularmente durante la semana.

**Qué pasó**
Un gran estudio con más de 50,000 adultos con diabetes mostró que incluso quienes hacen todo su ejercicio durante el fin de semana — llamados "guerreros de fin de semana" — tienen un riesgo mucho menor de morir por enfermedades cardíacas. De hecho, hacer 150 minutos de actividad moderada a intensa en uno o dos días es tan efectivo como repartirlo en varias sesiones durante la semana.

**Impacto**
El estudio encontró que los guerreros de fin de semana tenían un 33% menos de riesgo de morir por enfermedades cardíacas comparado con personas inactivas. También tenían un 21% menos de riesgo de muerte por cualquier causa. Esto significa que hacer ejercicio cuando sea posible puede marcar una gran diferencia para la salud del corazón, especialmente para quienes tienen diabetes.

**Siguiente paso**
Los médicos y expertos en salud pueden motivar a las personas con diabetes a alcanzar al menos 150 minutos de actividad por semana, aunque sea todo en el fin de semana. Hacer que el ejercicio sea flexible y realista ayuda a las personas a mantenerlo y proteger mejor su salud cardíaca.

**Una frase para recordar**
Solo dos entrenamientos a la semana pueden reducir drásticamente el riesgo de muerte cardíaca para personas con diabetes, demostrando que cualquier cantidad de ejercicio importa sin importar el horario.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a vibrant red heart shielded gently by two abstract figures made of flowing blue and green ribbons symbolizing exercise, with one figure showing a clock highlighting two segments to represent two weekly workouts, set against a soft, simple background of calming earth tones.
